1.text: “Do you know the time when the mountain goats give birth? Do you watch when the doe bears fawns?

2.text: Can you number the months that they fulfill? Or do you know the time when they give birth?

3.text: They bow themselves, they bring forth their young, they end their labor pains.

4.text: Their young ones become strong. They grow up in the open field. They go forth, and don’t return again.

5.text: “Who has set the wild donkey free? Or who has loosened the bonds of the swift donkey,

6.text: Whose home I have made the wilderness, and the salt land his dwelling place?

7.text: He scorns the tumult of the city, neither does he hear the shouting of the driver.

8.text: The range of the mountains is his pasture, He searches after every green thing.

9.text: “Will the wild ox be content to serve you? Or will he stay by your feeding trough?

10.text: Can you hold the wild ox in the furrow with his harness? Or will he till the valleys after you?

11.text: Will you trust him, because his strength is great? Or will you leave to him your labor?

12.text: Will you confide in him, that he will bring home your seed, and gather the grain of your threshing floor?

13.text: “The wings of the ostrich wave proudly; but are they the feathers and plumage of love?

14.text: For she leaves her eggs on the earth, warms them in the dust,

15.text: and forgets that the foot may crush them, or that the wild animal may trample them.

16.text: She deals harshly with her young ones, as if they were not hers. Though her labor is in vain, she is without fear,

17.text: because God has deprived her of wisdom, neither has he imparted to her understanding.

18.text: When she lifts up herself on high, she scorns the horse and his rider.

19.text: “Have you given the horse might? Have you clothed his neck with a quivering mane?

20.text: Have you made him to leap as a locust? The glory of his snorting is awesome.

21.text: He paws in the valley, and rejoices in his strength. He goes out to meet the armed men.

22.text: He mocks at fear, and is not dismayed, neither does he turn back from the sword.

23.text: The quiver rattles against him, the flashing spear and the javelin.

24.text: He eats up the ground with fierceness and rage, neither does he stand still at the sound of the trumpet.

25.text: As often as the trumpet sounds he snorts, ‘Aha!’ He smells the battle afar off, the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.

26.text: “Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars, and stretches her wings toward the south?

27.text: Is it at your command that the eagle mounts up, and makes his nest on high?

28.text: On the cliff he dwells, and makes his home, on the point of the cliff, and the stronghold.

29.text: From there he spies out the prey. His eyes see it afar off.

30.text: His young ones also suck up blood. Where the slain are, there he is.”
